media.caption: Lewis and Clark on the Lower Columbia, Charles Marion Russell, 1905

text.headline: Lewis and clark expedition
text.text: Appointed by Thomas Jefferson, Meriwether Lewis and William Clark left St. Louis, Missouri, in May 1804 and reached the Pacific Ocean near what would become Columbia, Oregon, in November 1805. Their main tasks were to survey the new lands west of the Mississippi River and to locate a water route to the Pacific.

text.headline: DECEMBER 1803 - MAY 1804
text.text:
In December 1803, William Clark established a camp on the Wood River. During his time at the camp, called Camp River Dubois, Clark trained the men who had volunteered to go to the Pacific as part of the "Corps of Discovery."

On May 14, the expedition was ready to begin. The Corps of Discovery left Camp River Dubois and was joined by Meriwether Lewis a week later.

text.headline: MAY 21, 1804
text.text: During the winter, when Clark and the Corps of Discovery were training at Camp River Dubois, Meriwether Lewis had spent time in St. Louis, Missouri, gathering supplies and getting ready for the expedition. Lewis also talked with fur traders who had been up the Missouri River, and obtained maps made by earlier explorers. On May 21, he joined the expedition in St. Charles.

text.headline: EARLY SUMMER 1804
text.text:
The Corps traveled up the Missouri River on Meriwhether Lewis's 55-foot-long keelboat, Discovery, and two smaller boats called pirogues, which they used to carry their supplies and equipment. The team averaged 10-15 miles per day.

On June 3rd, William Clark wrote in his diary, "I have a verry Sore Throat, 〈great〉 & am Tormented with Musquetors & Small ticks." Illness, injuries, and other obstacles made travel up the Missouri difficult and slow.

text.headline: JULY 4, 1804
text.text:
The Corps held the first Independence Day celebration west of the Mississippi River. They marked the occasion by firing Discovery's cannon and drinking an extra ration of whiskey.

On this day, Sergeant John Ordway wrote in his diary about naming a local creek in honor of the day: "We passed a Creek on the South Side about 15 yards wide... & as it is the 4 of July, Capts. name it Independence Creek. we fired our Bow piece this morning & one in the evening for Independance of the U. S."

media.caption: From A Journal of the Voyages and Travels of a Corps of Discovery (Philadelphia: Matthew Carey, 1812)

text.headline: AUGUST 3, 1804
text.text:
The Corps held a council with the Indian tribes of the region. As they did at many subsequent councils, the Corps handed out peace medals, American flags, and other gifts; demonstrated their technologies; and attempted to build a mutually beneficial relationship with the local Indians.

On this day, Clark wrote in his diary, "Prepare a Small preas[en]t for those Indians and hold a Councul ... Delivered a Speech & ... gave a fiew preasents and, a Smoke a Dram, Some Powder & Ball ...Those people express great Satisfa[ct]ion at the Speech Delivered."

text.headline: AUGUST 30, 1804
text.text:
The expedition conducted another friendly council with the local Yankton Sioux. The Yanktons accepted an invitation to send a delegation to Washington DC, where they would begin trade discussions with President Jefferson.

In his diary, William Clark wrote, "The Scioues Camps are handsom of a Conic form Covered with Buffalow Roabs Painted different colours and all compact & handsomly arranged."

text.headline: SEPTEMBER 25, 1804
text.text:
The Corps had a tense encounter with the Lakota people, also called the Teton Sioux. The Lakotas demanded one of the boats as a toll for moving farther upriver, and relations were tense on both sides.

Clark wrote in his diary about the encounter, "I call this Island bad humered Island as we were in a bad humer."

They narrowly avoided a fight, which was ultimately stopped by a chief, and the expedition left a few days later in a rather dramatic fashion.

text.headline: OCTOBER 24, 1804
text.text: The Corps arrived at the villages of the Mandan and Hidatsa, buffalo-hunting Indian tribes that lived along the Missouri River. The captains decided to build their winter quarters, called Fort Mandan, across the river from the main village.

text.headline: NOVEMBER 4, 1804
text.text:
The expedition hired Toussaint Charbonneau, a French Canadian fur trader living among the Hidatsas, as an interpreter. He brought his Shoshone wife, Sacagawea, who had been captured by the Hidatsas several years earlier and then sold to Charbonneau.

Clark wrote in his diary of Charbonneau and Sacagawea, "A french man by Name Chabonah, who Speaks the Big Belley language visit us, he wished to hire & informed us his 2 Squars were Snake Indians, we engau him to go on with us and take one of his wives to interpet the Snake language." Lewis and Clark hoped that the couple would be helpful with navigation and establishing cultural contacts.

media.caption: Reconstruction of Fort Mandan, Lewis and Clark Memorial Park, North Dakota

text.headline: DECEMBER 17, 1804
text.text: In his diary, Clark recorded, "a verry Cold morning. the Thrmt. Stood a[t] 43° below 0." A week later, the group finished building Fort Mandan and settled in for the winter.

text.headline: APRIL 29, 1805
text.text:
Lewis and another man encountered and killed a grizzly bear, an animal never before described for science. Galvanized by this initial victory, Lewis believed that Indian accounts of the bears’ ferocity were exaggerated. He wrote in his diary, "the Indians may well fear this anamal equiped as they generally are with their bows and arrows or indifferent fuzees, but in the hands of skillfull riflemen they are by no means as formidable or dangerous as they have been represented."

In the coming days, as the men encountered many rough grizzly bears that proved very difficult to kill, he began to change his mind.

text.headline: MAY 20, 1805
text.text:
The captains named a river after Sacagawea. Clark wrote, "this stream we called Sah ca gah we a or bird woman's River, after our interpreter the Snake woman."

As they mapped new territory, a landmark was named after every member of the expedition.

text.headline: MAY 31, 1805
text.text:
The Corps of Discovery entered the White Cliffs of the Missouri. The men were taken by the beauty of the white sandstone cliffs.

Clark remarked, "The Hills and river Clifts of this day exhibit a most romantick appearance. on each Side of the river is a white Soft Sand Stone bluff which rises to about half the hight of the hills, on the top of this Clift is a black earth on points, in maney places this Sand Stone appears like antient ruins some like elegant buildings at a disance."

text.headline: JUNE 13, 1805
text.text: Scouting ahead of the rest of the expedition, Lewis came across the Great Falls of the Missouri. When the rest of the expedition arrived, they began hauling the canoes and remaining supplies over the broken terrain. Although the captains originally planned for this to take half a day, it took nearly a month due to weather conditions and other obstacles.

text.headline: LATE JULY 1805
text.text: The expedition reached the Three Forks of the Missouri, which the captains named the Gallatin, the Madison, and the Jefferson.

text.headline: AUGUST 8, 1805
text.text:
Sacagawea pointed out the place where she was captured five years earlier. She believed that the expedition was nearing the river's headwaters, and the home of her people.

Lewis wrote, "the Indian woman recognized the point of a high plain to our right which she informed us was not very distant from the summer retreat of her nation on a river beyond the mountains which runs to the west." Desperate to find the Shoshone Indians and their horses, Lewis decided to scout ahead with three men.

text.headline: AUGUST 12, 1805
text.text: Lewis ascended the final ridge toward the Continental Divide. He was disappointed not to find the expected and highly anticipated Northwest Passage,  a water route believed to connect the Missouri River with the Pacific and the riches of the Orient.

text.headline: AUGUST 22, 1805
text.text:
On the brink of starvation, the entire expedition finally reached the end of the Bitterroot Mountains, which were very bitter to them indeed.

Patrick Gass, one of the men in the Corps, wrote in his diary for the day, "Game is scarce, and we killed nothing since the 18th but one deer; and our stock of provisions is exhausted."

text.headline: SEPTEMBER 9, 1805
text.text: The Corps camped at Travelers Rest, preparing for the mountain crossing. Local Indians informed them that by following the Missouri to its source, they missed a shortcut from the Great Falls that would have taken four days. Instead, it took the Corps of Discovery 53 days.

text.headline: SEPTEMBER 11, 1805
text.text: The Corps of Discovery ascended into the Bitterroot Mountains. Their local guide, called Old Toby, lost the trail in the steep and heavily wooded mountains. They struggled through the mountains with few provisions, and one of the men died. Clark named a stream "Hungry Creek," describing their condition.

text.headline: OCTOBER 7, 1805
text.text: The expedition acquired five new canoes which they launched into the Clearwater River. For the first time since leaving St. Louis, there was a river current at their back and the sailing was fairly easy.

text.headline: OCTOBER 16, 1805
text.text:
After racing down the Clearwater River, then the Snake River, the group reached the Columbia River. 

Gass wrote, "Having gone 21 miles we arrived at the great Columbia river, which comes in from the northwest. We found here a number of natives, of whose nations we have not yet found out the names. We encamped on the point between the two rivers. The country all round is level, rich and beautiful, but without timber."

text.headline: NOVEMBER 7, 1805
text.text: Thinking he saw the end of land in the distance, Clark wrote, "Great joy in camp we are in View of the Ocian, this great Pacific Octean which we been So long anxious to See. and the roreing or noise made by the waves brakeing on the rockey Shores (as I Suppose) may be heard distictly." However, they were actually only at the Columbia estuary, still 20 miles from sea. Due to storms and terrible sailing conditions, the group was forced to stay there for nearly three weeks.

text.headline: DECEMBER 1805 - MARCH 1806
text.text:
The expedition celebrated Christmas in Fort Clatsop, their 1805/06 winter quarters.

On March 23, Fort Clatsop was presented to the Clatsop Indians, and the expedition set off for home. Private Joseph Whitehouse recorded the day in his diary, "At 1 o'Clock P. M. we embarked, on board our Canoes from Fort Clatsop, on our homeward bound Voyage."
